2.author: NolanTheIrishman
2.body:
1. Is your windows attached to a Microsoft account? W10 just needs an activated login to work if so.
[info](https://www.windowscentral.com/how-re-activate-windows-10-after-hardware-change)
2. In the second video, you need to have an enabled hard drive along with the bootable USB for it to install on.

I'm guessing things went haywire on the original SSD if you did indeed turn it off in the middle of an install? It's best to never power off whenever changes are being made to a hard drive especially when it comes to installing operating systems or setting encryption etc. 
You might need to reformat the SSD completely before trying to use it again but I'm not 100% on that.

6.body: could be the CPU or GPU overheating. a GTX 950 is a pretty old card. have you ever had it repasted? are you monitoring temps? have you cleaned the laptop's cooling system?

6.author: wrath_of_grunge
6.body:
it's entirely possible that the AC adapter you got for it isn't working like it should. 

i would fire up a temp monitoring program and see if it's getting hot while running a game. 

the fans and stuff being clean are good. being repasted 3 or 4 years ago is also a good thing. it *might* be time to do it again.

6.author: iiGiovanni
6.body: I updated my post with images showing the statistics. Looks like it’s not because of the temperatures. Could you see if you have an idea?

6.author: wrath_of_grunge
6.body:
not 100% sure on this. but after disconnecting the charger you can see the clock speed is dropped. after reconnecting the charger the clock speed picks back up, but performance doesn't. that leads me to think it's possible that the CPU is getting stuck in a lower clock/power mode. 

i've got a older Windows tablet/laptop that does this from time to time. the fix for it is running ThrottleStop, which you've said you're already using. 

i think if i were you, and dealing with this, i would look into getting a proper replacement AC adapter. it can't be very much, and it would let you re-test and see if you still have issues. 

another thing you can check is the Nvidia Control Panel. i'd get rid of Geforce Experience. it's garbage and has the ability to change GPU settings on the fly, which can result in odd issues that crop up out of nowhere. 

anyways, in NVCP go to 3D Settings > Manage 3D Settings > Global Settings > Power Management Mode. set that to Prefer Maximum Performance. see if that corrects the issue.

12.author: Gnkey
12.body: If you noticed any sparks when you opened it - then it is a possibility, but rare one. This is what I would do - remove battery, of course, make sure that power adapter is not connected either. With battery removed and power adapter unplugged - press and hold laptop power button for, at least, 30 seconds. This will discharge static electricity - thus, if any microchips may got into weird state - this will take care of it. Then, very carefully reinsert the battery ( you may want, just in case, use a Q-tip with isopropyl alcohol and wipe battery connector and motherboard connector where you will align battery with) and try to power on laptop prior to closing the cover.

12.author: Interesting-Gas2857
12.body: Okay thank you! I’ll try these thing. And just out of curiosity, why use isopropyl alcohol?

12.author: Gnkey
12.body: Well, the 100% alcohol would be considered as the ideal material to clean any electronic contacts as they evaporate quickly and leave no residue behind.

15.author: pcbeg
15.body:
Usually problems like that after moving computer/laptop, indicates that cooler has slightly moved, and dried thermal paste has cracked under it, as a result you have air between cpu/gpu and cooler = worst cooling, fans working mode.

Normal solution would be cleaning, dusting, repasting cooler, and it should be already done by computer shop. Either they didn't do it, or they did it poorly, or cooler is damaged in some way and it has to be replaced.

21.author: Ch3vr0n
21.body: Windows can only extend to the right. The unallocated space is on the left. You need to use a third party partition manager to extend to the left, or move there data partition to the left so the unallocated space gets pushed to the right. And while you're at it, what do the partitions look like on your C drive. As that EFI and recovery shouldn't be on your D drive either. That's your boot record and windows recovery partition.

21.author: reddituser6997
21.body: My windows used to be on the hard drive and I cloned the partition with windows onto my ssd, thats why I have unallocated space left

21.author: Ch3vr0n
21.body:
Did you verify your system boots properly without the drive holding the D partition? If it does, you can delete that EFI and recovery partition too. It's not a whole lot of storage but it's still space being occupied that shouldn't be. If windows fails to boot with that drive disconnected, it still uses those partitions.

Either way for you to expand you need to move that D partition to the left so it pushes the unallocated to the right of your want to use windows' native partition expanding function.

27.author: Spectral_Hex
27.body:
I've just been reading up on game mode and checked if its on for me. It is but I've never had an issue with it.  
It shouldn't be slowing your software down to such a degree that you have problems, especially on an i9.  


This is what it does:  
"Uses DXGI flip model to suspend the desktop compositor when running borderless fullscreen (you had to use exclusive fullscreen in the past for best performance/latency), suppresses desktop notification, stops UI updates for modern apps/background apps that are not visible, slightly priorities the foreground game process in cases where CPU load nears 100%.".  


It really should not be causing you such problems. Is your CPU usage getting to  or near 100% when running these things?

I assume you mean 25 Megabytes per second, not 25 Megabits per second. That's still only 200 Megabits per second, which should leave you with 100 Megabits per second to spare, assuming your Internet connection is actually capable of running up to 300 Megabits per second.

What's your uplink bandwidth? Since you are on cable, it will be much less. You could be congesting the uplink. All communication with the Internet requires some uplink bandwidth, even if most of the data flow is in the downlink direction.

You may also want to check the logs in the modem and/or router. They may contain messages that may shed some light on what's going on.

30.author: TheEthyr
30.body:
If that speed test is accurate, then you could very well be congesting your downlink. Cable Internet is a shared medium, meaning that you share bandwidth with other, nearby neighbors. If there are a lot of neighbors, then there may be not be enough bandwidth for everyone to use their Internet connection at their max subscribed bandwidth. This is due to a practice called [oversubscription](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overselling). It’s similar to an airline selling more seats than are available on a plane. 

Your max speeds could also be limited by other factors. Your modem could have a weak connection to the ISP. There are guides for interpreting the signal levels available on the modem’s status page. As I mentioned before, you should log into the modem and look at the logs. 

You could try calling your ISP. You could say, “Hey, I’m not getting the 300 Mbps I paid for.” Set your expectations low. Many ISPs will tell you something along the lines of, “We only provide **up to 300 Mbps**”.

It might be interesting to know whether your devices can still ping each other when the problem is happening. This would help determine if the Internet connection is the problem or the router itself.

If you do determine that you are simply using up all of the bandwidth that your Internet connection is capable of, you can try turning QoS on the router. QoS can help manage bandwidth usage by devices. How well QoS works depends on the router. Some routers have poor QoS implementations and can actually make things worse. There’s no harm in trying it. You can always turn it off if it doesn’t help. 

In Steam, you can limit the bandwidth used for downloads. You might want to set it something like 150 Mbps. This should leave at least 50 Mbps for everything else.

40.author: hookonsonic2
40.body:
Contrary to what you're assuming, it might actually be the PSU.  That click sound could be one of the protection circuits kicking in due to some kind of short-circuit protection, or maybe something in the PSU is failing (12V rail to GPU, maybe?) and causing itself to power off instantly for protection.

It's hard to tell if the issue is the PSU or the GPU based on this alone.  This is probably a long shot, but you might be able to test the GPU by installing it without any power cables.  The motherboard power alone might be enough to cause a potential GPU issue to show up again and turn your computer off.  If that does end up happening, then it's the GPU.  If not, then it's hardly definitive enough to give a clear answer.  If you have a spare PSU or GPU, you could try testing those in various combinations to rule one part out.

60.author: rekabis
60.body:
I just realized - OP should try an external keyboard.

Any BIOS keyboard rebinding would likely only work for the built-in keyboard attached directly to the motherboard. It should _not_ affect any external USB keyboard.

Theoretically, an external USB keyboard - especially a normal full-sized one - should allow him to hit SHIFT+F10 without any issues.

60.author: rekabis
60.body:
I would still take the avoid-network route even if your next laptop is working just fine and does indeed see the network. 

Why? So you can use the next step, and set up a local account in order to ignore the requirement for a Microsoft account.

Using a Microsoft Account is potentially dangerous, as that depends on the security of that account. And since Microsoft limited password length to 16 characters for so long (up until a few short years ago, AFAIR), many accounts are still woefully unprotected, and ripe for cracking by bad actors. And once your Microsoft account is cracked, you really don’t have an easy way back into your physical computer other than a wipe-and-reinstall.

Honestly, use only a local account with a decent password. There are other tools that can back your data up to the cloud, or track your laptop if it ever gets stolen.

60.author: 404OWLS
60.body: I actually stumbled upon some forum discussions about this topic when trying to troubleshoot my laptop. Pretty scary stuff I’d never heard of before. Thank you for the warning!

60.author: rekabis
60.body:
There are two different levels of Microsoft account integration:

1. Superficial, such that your Office documents are automatically saved to OneDrive and so forth
2. Integrated, such that you log onto your computer using your Microsoft account instead of a local account

The first is annoying for privacy purists, but OK. In fact, because your Office subscription/key is connected to your Microsoft account, you kind of have no choice if you want to run Office in any way that allows you to port your license if you change computers.

The second is the scary one. If your Microsoft account is ever compromised and your password changed, you are suddenly locked out of your own computer. It gets even worse if you have Bitlocker enabled, as your stuff is then encrypted and impossible to just yoink off the drive.

Which is why you always want to be able to create a local account on system setup. You can always log into your Microsoft account through the Windows 10/11 system settings such that it is _hooked into_ your local account in that superficial method, but _you definitely want that local account._

Good luck with your next laptop!

75.author: Alucard256
75.body:
Most wireless access points and wireless routers can theoretically have 255 devices connected at a time.

This sounds like interference more to me. Is the wifi on 2.4Ghz or 5Ghz? Remember that 2.4Ghz wifi signals can be interfered with by 1990's style "cordless" phones, baby monitors, and poorly shielded (aka: cheap) microwaves.

*All of which* are likely to be *all around you* in an RV park.

75.author: MyDogActuallyFucksMe
75.body: There are both frequencies available, but since all the access points are the exact same name they both show up as a single wifi point to the PC so I can't pick whoch one I want, unless maybe I remove the 2.4 antenna from the wireless card.

75.author: Alucard256
75.body:
Forcing your side to use 5Ghz might produce different results at least.

Just remember that 5Ghz is *much more* susceptible to physical line-of-sight obstacles between your device and the access point. An RV passing between could interrupt the 5Ghz signal for a moment... possibly long enough to officially loose connection. Then again, if it's a tree in the way, moving your device a few feet to the side might make a huge difference.

99.author: LesleyN00
99.body:
If you can't access the BIOS, you could try the following steps:  
  
\- Disconnect all external devices (e.g. USB drives, printers, etc.) except for the keyboard and mouse.  
\- Reset the CMOS by removing the CMOS battery for 10-15 seconds and then re-inserting it.  
\- Try using a different keyboard or a PS/2 keyboard instead of a USB one.  
\- If you have another computer available, try booting your hard drive as a secondary drive in that computer to check if your files are still accessible.  
\- If none of the above steps work, you may need to consider seeking professional repair services or reaching out to the manufacturer for assistance.

99.author: metsfanapk
99.body:
The files are still there. 

Where would the CMOS battery be? and what would that do?

99.author: LesleyN00
99.body:
>The files are still there.  
>  
>Where would the CMOS battery be? and what would that do?

The CMOS battery is a small battery that provides power to the motherboard's CMOS (Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor) chip, which stores important information such as system configuration settings and the date/time.  
  
To reset the CMOS, you need to locate the battery on your motherboard and remove it for 10-15 seconds, then re-insert it. This will reset the CMOS to its default settings, which may help resolve the issue you're experiencing.  
  
The exact location of the CMOS battery can vary depending on the motherboard model, but it's usually a small coin-shaped battery located near the CMOS chip or the battery socket on the motherboard. You can refer to the motherboard manual or look up the motherboard model online to find its specific location.

99.author: metsfanapk
99.body: I assume I do that with the pc unplugged?

99.author: LesleyN00
99.body:
>I assume I do that with the pc unplugged?

Yes, you should turn off the PC, unplug it from the power source, and remove the battery when resetting the CMOS. This is to prevent any electrical interference or damage to the components. After you have removed the battery, wait for 10-15 seconds, and then re-insert it and plug the PC back in. Then start the PC to see if the issue has been resolved.

100.author: LesleyN00
100.body:
Here are some steps that you can try to minimize the impact of other devices on your gaming experience:  
  
\- Prioritize your gaming traffic: You can use Quality of Service (QoS) settings on your router to give higher priority to your gaming traffic, which can reduce lag spikes.  
  
\- Separate gaming and other traffic: You can use a separate network for gaming and connect your gaming PC to it using a wired connection, which can prevent interference from other devices on the same network.  
  
\- Upgrade to a better router: If your router does not have QoS features, you can consider upgrading to a better router that supports QoS and has better network management capabilities.  
  
\- Use a gaming VPN: A gaming VPN can help you reduce lag by routing your traffic through a server that is closer to the gaming servers, which can lower your ping.  
  
\- Monitor network usage: You can use a network monitoring tool to track your bandwidth usage and identify which devices or applications are consuming the most bandwidth.  
  
These are some steps you can try to improve your gaming experience while other devices are also using the internet. It may also be helpful to reach out to your ISP to see if they have any suggestions or solutions.

100.author: Ungoliant0
100.body:
Thanks for your reply!

Can you explain a bit how QOS works in relation to this problem? Will it prevent other devices from using the entire bandwidth? Is there any router that you recommend?

I've been thinking of getting the deco x60 (for wireless devices + my PC that will be connected with a cable to one of the nodes). [Seems like QOS is available for it.](https://www.tp-link.com/us/support/faq/1601/) Do you know if the x60 QOS is any decent?

Regarding the other suggestions. I assume that the VPN doesn't directly has to do with the issue? is that right?

Do you have any recommendation for network monitoring apps?

Also, I would like to make sure I understood. You're saying that other devices basically momentarily use the entire bandwidth, which is enough to reflect in the ping spikes?

100.author: LesleyN00
100.body:
Yes, that's correct. When other devices on the same network consume bandwidth, it can cause lag spikes in your gaming experience.  
  
Quality of Service (QoS) allows you to set priorities for different types of network traffic, so that critical applications, such as gaming, receive the necessary bandwidth to function properly. This can help reduce lag spikes caused by other devices on the network.  
  
The TP-Link Deco X60 does have QoS features and is a good option for your situation. However, I would recommend checking the reviews and specifications of different routers before making a decision, to make sure it meets your needs and supports the features you require.  
  
Regarding VPNs, they can help reduce lag by routing your gaming traffic through a server that is closer to the gaming servers, which can lower your ping. However, they won't directly solve the issue of other devices consuming bandwidth and causing lag spikes on your network.  
  
For network monitoring, you can use tools such as GlassWire, NetSpeedMonitor, or Wireshark. These tools can provide you with information on which devices or applications are consuming the most bandwidth, allowing you to identify potential sources of interference.  
  
In summary, QoS can help prevent other devices from consuming bandwidth that is necessary for your gaming traffic, reducing lag spikes. I recommend checking the specifications and reviews of different routers before choosing one, and using a network monitoring tool to monitor your network usage.
